54 EUGIPPIUS

man of God addressed the people in many discourses. He persuaded the priests of the place to enjoin a three days’ fast3 and he instructed that waxen tapers should be brought from each house, and that every- one should fasten his taper with his own hand to the wall of the church. Then, when the customary psalm-singing was completed‚ and the hour of the sacrifice arrived, the man of God exhorted the priests and deacons that with all alacrity of heart they should join him in prayer to their common Lord; that the Lord might show the light of his knowledge to dis- tinguish those guilty of sacrilege. So while he was praying with them at great length, weeping much, and on his knees, the greater part of the tapers, those namely which the faithful had brought, were sud- denly kindled by divine agency. The rest remained unlighted, being the tapers of those who had been polluted by the aforesaid sacrilege, but, wishing to remain hidden, had denied it. Thus those who had placed them were revealed by the divine test; and straightway they cried out, and by their behavior sufficiently betrayed the secrets of their hearts. Con- victed by the witness of their tapers, and by open confession, they bore witness to their own sacrilegious acts.
